subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: ... This is where I disagree with the use of mocks. I have to thank you, David, for putting this example in the spotlight. The second test may be better if it
messageBody:
>So said David Boyer on 2003-08-01 --------------------
>On Thu, 2003-07-31 at 21:20, Adam Jack wrote:
>
>> Ok, another example. I have a class that walks a classpath and generates
>> listener events on things found, I test that. I have a class that
>listens to
>> such events to "find" things that match a certain criterion, I test
>that. If
>> the first class fails to send events, then I ought not blame (or dig
>into)
>> the second for not finding anything. The tests are (I believe) unit
>tests of
>> each, without duplication.
>Ok, here, The first class, the classpath walker, is fine. However, the
>second class should use a mockobject version of the classpathwalker.
>ClasspathWalker should be an interface. This way you can test your own
>reaction to fake events. Ones which you control and aren't dependent on
>the classpath walker OR ON THE CLASSES IN THE PATH.

This is where I disagree with the use of mocks. I have to thank you, David, for putting this example in the spotlight.

The second test may be better if it depends on the data from the classpath walker, rather than a mock classpath walker. Presumably the mock classpath walker will be implemented to hardcode specified classpath walking data, anyway. I propose to extract the classpath walking data, then, and pass it to the second object, rather than mocking a classpath walker.

Thoughts?

PS: If you do this, then the tests become 100% isolated as a side effect of avoiding extra code.
